title: 1 Million Members, 100 Million Trees: How Brazil’s Socialist Farmers Are Fighting Big Ag

last_post.content:
Municipal nurseries can be a huge driver of social and political change. The Landless Workers Movement in Brazil are doing agroecological projects by making collective nurseries to help revive the native ecosystem and organize the working class.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KiXkUPeMx9I

They are an intersectional ecosocialist movement with Black and Indigenous people leading the fight against agro-businesses and the capitalist class that exploits the people and the ecosystem. They also do land occupations to take back land for the people. Deforestation is a major issue in Brazil, this is done almost exclusively by corporations and wealthy land owners who only see the land as a profit machine, and not a delicate ecosystem that can be managed in responsible ways borrowing from the experience of the local people. We could learn a lot from movements like this, and tailor tactics and methods to our bioregions and communities. By learning methods from agroecology, permaculture, and indigenous communities we can figure out better ways to sustain the ecosystem and each other.

Land occupations and squats to build ecosocialist - intersectional - and communal life while repairing the ecosystem with native biodiversity is amazing. Giving land back to indigenous people, and the working class to steward the land is a worthy fight.https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1sZ0FMJqefw

#solarpunk #ecosocialism

#geoweirdness

We haven't done much with #Bicycling #Monterey's YouTube channel—mostly because we provide bikemonterey.org and all bike advocacy projects to date (May 2009-April 2023) as a volunteer and simply can't do more tasks; and partly because #YouTube is a Google company.

Nonetheless, we posted our new video on YouTube this week "ANDAR EN BICICLETA EN LAS ACERAS además de ejemplos de ordenanzas del Condado de Monterey, California," including transcript/subtitles.

That motivated us to type up subtitles for 2 short #videos we'd previously posted on our channel: "BikeMonterey.org - Sea Otter Classic, a Celebration of Cycling - Detox!" and "BikeMonterey.org - HER Helmet Thursdays welcome from Alvarado St, Monterey."

We truly appreciate those (even bots) for reminding of importance of #subtitles, photo #descriptions, #AltText, etc. Just wish for more hours in the day to provide them, including time required to write better #PhotoDescriptions.

#DoWhatYouCan #BikeTooter

https://youtu.be/pkH8V3hFlns

For those of you that don't own a house yet, here's one thing that you may not realize: lawn maintenance and upkeep is a constant time-consuming task. If your house is in a neighborhood with an HOA (which is almost all of them nowadays), it's also a task you cannot ignore. Your options are to do it yourself (time-consuming) or pay others to do it (expensive). If you don't do it and run afoul of your HOA, you can find yourself drowning in fees and fines and possibly even lose your house. Lawn upkeep is just one of the ways one can arouse the ire of the HOA.

John Oliver's latest Last Week Tonight highlighted the lunacy that is HOAs in the US.

Edit: I'm hearing that the video is US-only, so you might have to find it elsewhere. It should be available on HBO Max, if you have that.

title: Cocktail Robotics Grand Challenge: Quarantine Edition, 22 Nov 2020 at DNA Lounge

last_post.content:
@dec23k @gothnbass @Wrecks0 @robin
I fear that our Cocktail Robotics Grand Challenge might be another COVID casualty. Our last one was online, during lockdown in 2020 -- more of a documentary, really, and it was awesome. We put so much work into it! https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hG43acu28p4

We tried to do it live again in Nov 2021, but were forced to cancel due to lack of entrants, and we haven't tried again since. I suspect we've now lost the little momentum we had... Too many of our core group have moved away and/or junked their robots.

Everyone loves to *attend* the event, but finding enough *makers* was always a huge challenge.

@Curator @FacemanArt @LoadCake @Hinrt @wobblylines @marceles_pixel @subtlemoss @hokuyu @hovkinnie @Mtomate @tinydharla

We have a lot to learn about how to govern shared spaces better, software or otherwise. What frustrates me, though, about DAO approaches is the lack of awareness of Elinor Ostrom's work (among others). There is Nobel prize winning work in how to collaboratively own resources we could emulate and model. Instead, a subset of VCs is hanging their hat on popularity polls.

Folding Ideas has a great takedown of DAOs (while also sassing the Metaverse) here: https://youtu.be/EiZhdpLXZ8Q?t=4923

title: "Unlocking the Power of Open Security Standards" - Cameron Tudball (Everything Open 2023)

last_post.content:
Today in our #EverythingOpen redux, we present @ctudball, who takes us on a tour of how the #InfoSec landscape has changed, the move to #ZeroTrust, #OpenStandards efforts, and the advent of #OCSF - a standard #taxonomy for representing #SIEM events, and the platform-agnostic @opentelemetry.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6o6YlTE-PzQ
New lovely #JethroTull video just dropped https://youtu.be/OfTwLaaXwqo
The full AlphaGo documentary is on YouTube. https://youtu.be/WXuK6gekU1Y
